subject: Retry ebtables on race
commit_message:
Retry ebtables on race

Calls to ebtables can race with libvirt and cause nova, or libvirt
to fail to apply ebtables rules.

The goal of this patch is to provide a simple fix to improve the
stability of the gate.

We now call ebtables in a simple loop that retries on failure.
Long term we want to update nova to make use of the --concurrent
flag in newer versions of ebtables. The --concurrent flag
implements a lock to prevent multiple invocations of ebtables from
racing. This will require a newer libvirt and the ability to
timeout long running execs (--concurrent can block forever if it
never gets the lock).

A future patch is forthcoming to add support for --concurrent.

DocImpact
Add ebtables_exec_attempts option (default=3).

Change-Id: I3e04782ac4678581462f9bee4bb10d5f3b223457
Partial-Bug: #1316621

subject: Make error limits survive a ring reload
commit_message:
Make error limits survive a ring reload

The proxy was storing the error count and last-error time in the
ring's internal data, specifically in the device dictionaries. This
works okay, but it means that whenever a ring changes, all the error
stats reset.

Now the error stats live in the proxy server object, so they survive a
ring reload.

Better yet, the error stats are now keyed off of the node's
IP/port/device triple, so if you have the same device in two rings
(like with multiple storage policies), then the error stats are
combined. If the proxy server sees a 507 for an objec request in
policy X, then that will now result in that particular object disk
being error-limited for requests in policies Y and Z as well.

Change-Id: Icc72b68b99f37367bb16d43688e7e45327e3e022

When a lock can't be acquired there is currently a hard coded
delay (0.01) that is used before trying again, instead of having

commit_message:
Fixed a problem with neutron http policy check

When a rule "create_network": "http://127.0.0.1:8080/ or rule:default"
is configured in policy.json, create network with default values reports
a "Circular reference detected" exception.
The reason is, for unspecified values, default value of
neutron.api.v2.attributes.ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED (that is, object())
is assigned by Neutron.
This creates a problem when jsonutils.dumps() is executed on a JSON
string that contains object(), thus reporting the said exception.
The fix replaces object() into empty value {} in the
dictionary, only for the policy check.

over several days (maybe forever if we don't restart the service). Other
pollsters in same thread will not be able to work too. The worst thing is
that, when outside (keystone) service becomes normal, Ceilometer cannot
recover itself automatically, cloud operator needs to restart it manually.

So I strongly suggest that we should add timeout limit to **every** rest api
call, this is quite important to improve Ceilometer's robust and reliability.

This patch adds a new option named http_timeout, and applies it to almost
all http requests in Ceilometer project.

Support iSCSI live migration for different iSCSI target

Currently, Nova premises a situation which iSCSI target is not changed
before and after live migration. Therefore, if destination node has
different iSCSI target, the live migration fails in current Nova's
specification. However, if each compute node uses same iSCSI target,
each compute node recognizes all volumes in the iSCSI target and this
is undesirable situation from the view point of security.

iSCSI targets to access the volumes.

of LUNs for each initiator within one iSCSI target, using same iSCSI

subject: Subnet delete for IPv6 SLAAC should not require prior port disassoc
commit_message:
Subnet delete for IPv6 SLAAC should not require prior port disassoc

With the current Neutron implementation, a subnet cannot be deleted
until all associated IP addresses have been remove from ports (via
port update) or the associated ports/VMs have been deleted.

In the case of SLAAC-enabled subnets, however, it's not feasible to
require removal of SLAAC-generated addresses individually from each
associated port before deleting a subnet because of the multicast
nature of RA messages. For SLAAC-enabled subnets, the processing of
subnet delete requests needs to be changed so that these subnets will
be allowed to be deleted, and all ports get disassociated from their
corresponding SLAAC IP address, when there are ports existing on
the SLAAC subnet.

subject: Use saner options for NFS mounts
commit_message:
Use saner options for NFS mounts

Cinder currently doesn't have use any options to mount NFS shares.
Although this works for most cases, it doesn't provide any feedback to
Cinder when things go wrong or the share is gone. This patch proposes a,
perhaps, saner default options to use that can be overwritten by the
user at any time. Here's the detail of what each option does:

soft -> report an error back when an nfs operation fails
timeo -> timeout for each nfs action
retrans -> number of times an nfs request should be retried

A note about using `soft` taken from NFS's manpage:

NB: A so-called "soft" timeout can cause silent data corruption in
certain cases. As such, use the soft option only when client
responsiveness is more important  than  data  integrity. Using NFS over
TCP or increasing the value of the retrans option may mitigate some of
the risks of using the soft option.

There's one case left un-handled by this patch. The options proposed
here don't handled mount operations that may remain hung. In order to do
that, 2 more options should be added: `fg,retry=0`. However, I think
these one deserves a dedicated patch since current mount failures,
AFAICT, are ignored or at least not handled correctly for this scenario.

subject: Don't run a query to check if the network exists
commit_message:
Don't run a query to check if the network exists

If the network does not exist, the query that inserts the port will
fail with a foreign key constraint failure.  This code is an attempt
to detect that and throw the NetworkNotFound exception when it is
caught.  This accomplishes the same goal as running
self._get_network(...) in the old code but without the extra query in
the non-exceptional case.  The non-exceptional case makes up the vast
majority of the times through this code path.

The old code doesn't use the result of the extra query for anything
else.  So, the ability to catch the error without incurring a DB call
is a performance gain.  How big?  It is hard to tell.   If nothing
else, this is a better database access pattern.

subject: Fix connecting unnecessary iSCSI sessions issue
commit_message:
Fix connecting unnecessary iSCSI sessions issue

In Icehouse with "iscsi_use_multipath=true", attaching a multipath
iSCSI volume may create unnecessary iSCSI sessions.

The iscsiadm discovery command in connect_volume() returns all of the
targets in the Cinder node, not just the ones related to the multipath
volume which is specified by iqn.  If the storage has many targets,
connecting to all these volumes will also result in many unnecessary
connections.

There are two types of iSCSI multipath devices.  One which shares
the same iqn between multiple portals, and the other which use
different iqns on different portals. connect_volume() needs to
identify the type by checking iscsiadm the output if the iqn is
used by multiple portals.

This patch changes the behavior of attaching volume:

   1. Identify the type by checking the iscsiadm output.
   2. Connect to the correct targets by connect_to_iscsi_portal().

Closes-Bug: #1382440

Change-Id: I488ad0c09bf26a609e27d67b9ef60b65bb45e0ad
